Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Scale-free continuum percolation of bubbles as a universal mechanism of the boiling crisis

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Boiling heat transfer is an exceptionally effective heat removal process and plays a critical role in electronics cooling, chemical processing, power generation, HVAC, and water purification. However, boiling is susceptible to a degradation, known as a boiling crisis, which may result in cooling system failures. Understanding this boiling crisis is key to the development and safe operations of nuclear reactors and computer processing units that rely on liquid-vapor two-phase cooling. Despite decades of research, the mechanism triggering a boiling crisis remains unclear and controversial. In this project, a new stochastic model is proposed based on the analogy between the boiling process and the formation of traffic jams. The project seeks to offers a novel perspective of boiling heat transfer to the thermal community. It also provides multidisciplinary STEM training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students, as well as young researchers.

This project will investigate boiling crises as a critical transition in the bubble coalescence process. The instability will be captured with a stochastic percolation model based on four fundamental boiling parameters: bubble wait time and growth time, bubble footprint radius, and nucleation site density. With a critical combination of these four parameters, the boiling crisis occurs when all the bubbles suddenly merge together. This hypothesis has recently been validated on smooth surfaces, in both pool and flow boiling conditions, as well as preliminary results on engineered surfaces. In the proposed work, the universality of the hypothesis will be tested by analyzing the boiling behavior of various surfaces and fluids, at different pressures, and under diverse flow conditions. The project will be accomplished through novel boiling experiments that combine state-of-the-art infrared diagnostics and post-processing algorithms, which enable measurements of time-dependent temperature and heat flux distributions on the boiling surface, as well as other boiling heat transfer parameters. The results of the experimental investigations will be shared with the thermal science and engineering community to support the evaluation of other models and stimulate the development of new ones.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Developing efficient heat removal techniques is a critical step towards the development and commercialization of next-generation high-performance electronic devices, cooling systems, and power generation and chemical processing units. To achieve this goal, boiling heat transfer is a very attractive solution, due to a large amount of heat transferred during the nucleation of bubbles, as well as during the quenching phase following their departure from the heated surface. Noticeably, as the heat flux increases, boiling becomes even more efficient: vapor production increases due to the activation of more bubble nucleation sites, and so does the heat transfer coefficient (HTC), keeping the heat generating system at low temperature. However, if the heat flux exceeds the critical heat flux (CHF) limit, the bubbles merge together, and the heating surface gets covered by a stable vapor blanket. This leads to a deterioration of the heat transfer process, which results in a rapid surface temperature rise, often leading to burnout. It is therefore essential to develop cooling techniques to increase the heat transfer coefficient, but also and more importantly, to enhance the CHF limits. In spite of decades of research, the mechanism triggering the boiling crisis remains an unsolved mystery. This project leveraged micro/nano-surface engineering to conduct high-pressure pool and flow boiling, reveal and justify, both theoretically and experimentally, the existence of a unifying criterion of the boiling crisis. A systematic measurement of the time-dependent temperature and heat flux distributions on the boiling surface, and several other fundamental boiling heat transfer parameters such as bubble growth time and wait time, nucleation site density, and bubble size distributions were possible through special boiling experiments making use of advanced infrared diagnostics and post-processing algorithms. The insights gained from this fundamental analysis suggests that the boiling crisis occurs on a well-defined critical surface in the multidimensional space of these parameters. The experiments confirm the existence of this unifying criterion for a wide variety of boiling surface geometries and textures and for two boiling regimes (pool and flow boiling). This criterion constitutes a simple mechanistic rule to predict the boiling crisis, also providing a guiding principle for designing boiling surfaces that would maximize the nucleate boiling performance.
